ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Interesting and very advanced seminar, builds on prior knowledge. Anyone interested in Energy Technology Innovation should take this class. Instructor is very available, mostly if you have an independent project.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Working with other energy students to discuss relevant advanced topics.
I enjoyed being in a room with lots of other knowledgeable energy students.
The case studies were real opportunities for learning
In-class discussion regarding policies that drive rapid energy transitions were often interesting. Instructor feedback was most useful in this context.

The bevy of literature available - the assigned material and the supplementary reading - was intriguing and very helpful. I thoroughly enjoyed our class discussions, and I learned just as much from my peers as from my instructor.

The in class discussions. It is a space where students can benefit from the experience of the professor and their classmates. It also fosters the capacity to analyze and criticize points made by the seminar participants.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The subject matter is too theoretical and big picture. I know that's what the course syllabus says it will be, so it's my error for taking it. If you wanted to go on a PhD, this would be a great course. If you want to enter the working world, I just don't think it is all that relevant. I love Prof. Grubler. ESA was my favorite class at FES. But this wasn't ESA 2.0, which is what I'd hoped and assumed it would be.

This course is a seminar, but I think students could gain more from the class if some adjustments are made. The online forum could be improved. Although a student provides a summary and directs the discussion, reading the entire article is sometimes necessary to get the context and a deeper understanding. Instead, submitting a written synthesis and assessment could be more beneficial. Also writing a number of policy memos could make this class an even stronger learning opportunity. Class discussions should also be more centered on the reading materials which normally form the foundation of knowledge on the issue.
Some of of the lectures and readings were outdated and/or dull.
There was not enough debrief of the on-line debates during the seminar. A comment by the professor or the TA could help clarify some of the doubts raised or the discussions happening in the blog.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The relationship was effective, but could be improved as mentioned above

The LSM transition analysis instructions need to be re-written. They confused every single person in our class, and our questions were never clarified adequately. We cannot learn how to use a model if we're not taught how to use it. The model's manual uses examples that are far too basic to be helpful. The TA needs to help us much more with this assignment. Contrary to his beliefs, lots of people - yes, even intelligent ones - need some form a of instruction to get them going. "Figuring things out on our own" doesn't work for everyone. If it did, no form of institutional education would be necessary. Some pedagogical training would go a long way to prove that instruction if invaluable and actually leads to more learning on one's own.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Have had a career in Energy and wanted to enhance my knowledge.
I am interested in clean energy and climate change. This course addresses the drivers and nature of energy transitions. This is clearly relevant to my interests.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to take another course with Prof. Grubler.
Advanced knowledge of Technology Innovation
To take a deeper dive into the energy field. To have access to small group setting where relevant energy topics could be discussed.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
No, but my expectations weren't in line with what the course tried to provide students.
I could have benefited more.
I did not get as much out of this course as I had hoped. The discussion and takeways were more general, and the modeling exercise was less technical and useful than I had expected.
The ETI Framework was my main takeaway from the course. This will allow me to break an "Energy Transition" problem into the key components in order to analyze them separately.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This is not ESA 2.0, it's a slow, theoretical divide into energy transitions on the 100-year scale. It does not cover much knowledge that I would consider practical or relevant for most FES energy students. I enjoyed being with Prof. Grubler and the class at times because he is brilliant and the class was full of energy kids. But I mostly did not get much from the course and would have not taken it, had I had the chance to do it all over again.
You will get more from this class if you have a project.
This may be a useful class for those interested in energy policy. However, it is not particularly inspiring.

The lectures cover topics that might be too high level and difficult to connect to applicable situations. However, the ETI framework is very useful to analyze energy transition challenges. The class discussions are very valuable and engaging.
